status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid responding to a gas leak on your street activated an emergency permit. Emergency work must be performed no matter what time of day or night in the interest of public safety and the protection of private property. This proved to be a very difficult repair, resulting in National Grid working into the night. We did find out from National Grid that after the first night of emergency work they did leave the work zone during the day. National Grid is required to do mandatory follow up testing of the leak repairs and they ended up finding another leak, and that is why they came back again. The work is now completed. I have asked Terry Cleary of National Grid to respond to you since obviously they are the experts regarding emergency gas repairs. Terry can be reached at teresa.cleary@nationalgrid.com. On behalf of the City we apologize that you had to put up with the gas leak repairs on off hours. If you want to discuss this matter further, please don't hesitate to contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

I just downloaded the :311 app because I'm very concerned with what has become of rose kennedy greenway by Hanover. To my shock and dismay it appears that this part of the beloved greenway is effectively a homeless encampment now. I have lived a block from here for over a decade and I bring my children here in the summer to play in the water. I won't anymore because the other day we went here and to our sadness during the day, the water fountains had been taken over.In addition to the crazy amounts of rats that now roam this ground, probably in part because of all the trash and food left. it appears that the drug addicts and homeless have become a mainstay of this once treasure in the city. It is such a disappointing thing to see... I would happily pay more in taxes to provide shelter to these individuals, but the situation has really gotten out of control. Are you even allowed to sleep in the greenway? Thanks. Next time I'll take a picture to highlight the scope of the issue
address: Intersection Of Cross St & Salem St, Boston

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The PWD Roadway Repair Contractor is working on your street performing patch paving. It is an important city service for your neighborhood to provide the best permanent repairs of previous utility excavations or potholes.  The construction process is to dig out 6.5 inches of material and place 5 inches of dense binder hot mix asphalt in 2 lifts. The dense binder gives the patch its strength but is has large stones and is not conducive to providing a smooth ride, the contractor usually within a week comes back and places 1.5 inches of the top course. The top course is hot mix asphalt  that provides the smooth ride. The street is leafleted before the work begins where it explains that it is a mufti phase construction operation and you should look at the dates since they will change as each construction phases progresses.  Our goal is to allow parking between phases and not post the street for the entire time the work takes place. This is why the contractor repeatedly changes the dates. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused.  Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

The sidewalk on the side of the Hebrew Rehabilitation Hospital no longer exists, and the addition of the lane for straight ahead traffic and bicycle traffic at the new traffic light makes walking very dangerous. Crossing the street to the existing sidewalk on the Arboretum side is not an option if one wishes to be on the hospital side of Centre St because crossing at the intersection itself is very dangerous with no crosswalk. I believe that the hospital should be forced to replace the sidewalk that was removed when the hospital was built. The addition of the new traffic light and the new traffic pattern on Walter St make walking on the hospital side of Walter St perilous since drivers round the corner too fast and have to swerve into the left only lane to avoid a walker. The current situation is a problem for both walkers and drivers. If looked at carefully, the grass where the sidewalk should be shows signs of foot traffic, a sure indication that a sidewalk is needed in this location.

status_notes: Case Noted. This signs, recently observed in green, were not stapled to the trees in this area by the City. Neither the BTD of Parks has certified these signs, and stapling them to the trees intended to be protected is not an appropriate manner of persuading cyclists not to affix bikes to the trunk or fences. The BTD does visit locations where cases are raised in order to tag the bikes with notes instructing the owners not to attach to trees so that the health of them might not be compromised. If the bikes remain after several days with the tag still on (indicating that it is unclaimed), the BTD does cut the lock and keeps the bike for a minimum of 30 days.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for your concern regarding the Quincy Street Reconstruction Project between Blue Hill Avenue and Columbia Road.  As you know certain sections of Quincy Street are under active construction and we apologize for any disturbances to your daily life.  During construction, we try to make sure that the contractor completes their work quickly, safely, and with minimal disruptions to traffic, however, we understand that this may be an inconvenience.  We ask that the community please be patient with us during this time. Regarding the curb extensions that are being installed, Public Works was tasked with making intersections along Quincy Street safer for pedestrians and to calm traffic by reducing vehicular speeds along the corridor during off-peak times.  The curb extensions at some corners are being installed to provide shorter crossing distances and improve visibility for pedestrians.  The result of these improvements is a slightly narrowed roadway at certain locations.  The curb bump-outs, lane widths, and overall roadway widths were carefully designed to be consistent with City Standards while working to accomplish the aforementioned safety goals.  Additionally, vehicle turning movement analysis was performed at intersections with curb line changes to confirm that there is adequate space for large or passenger vehicular traffic to safely maneuver through the intersection.  Public Works will continue to monitor traffic maneuverability along the corridor as the project is being constructed and will make any necessary adjustments if it be determined that adequate vehicular maneuverability is precluded by these changes.
description: Sidewalk bump outs, are impacting the school buses and larger vehicles from safely making turn from either ends of Ceylon st onto Quincy st.
address: Intersection Of Quincy St & Ceylon St, Dorchester

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for your interest in making our streets safer. The City of Boston recently opted in to adopt a lower default speed limit of 25 mph unless otherwise posted. Default speed limits are citywide, and are not posted on each block. However, we have installed several 25 mph signs at entry points to city streets. The speed bumps and 20 mph speed limit proposed are part of the City?s Neighborhood Slow Streets initiative. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.
